question_plain: Estimate the fraction of molecular volume to the actual volume occupied by oxygen gas at STP. Take the diameter of an oxygen molecule to be 3 Å.
question_latex: Estimate the fraction of molecular volume to the actual volume occupied by oxygen gas at STP. Take the diameter of an oxygen molecule to be $3$ Å.
hint: Find volume of 1 mole of O₂ molecules (N_A × V_molecule). Divide by molar volume at STP (22.4 L).
solution_steps_latex: Diameter of O$_2$ molecule: $d = 3$ Å $= 3 \times 10^{-10}$ m
Molar volume at STP: $V_m = 22.4$ L $= 22.4 \times 10^{-3}$ m$^3$
**Step 2:** Total volume of molecules in 1 mole:
**Step 3:** Fraction of molecular volume to actual volume:
• Molecules occupy only $0.04\%$ of the total volume
• This justifies the assumption that molecules are point particles in ideal gas theory

to_find: Fraction of molecular volume to actual volume

section: Ideal Gas Law and Molar Volume
question_plain: Molar volume is the volume occupied by 1 mol of any (ideal) gas at standard temperature and pressure (STP: 1 atmospheric pressure, 0 °C). Show that it is 22.4 litres.
question_latex: Molar volume is the volume occupied by $1$ mol of any (ideal) gas at standard temperature and pressure (STP: $1$ atmospheric pressure, $0$ °C). Show that it is $22.4$ litres.
hint: Use ideal gas equation: PV = nRT at STP conditions.
solution_steps_latex: **Conclusion:** At STP, 1 mole of any ideal gas occupies $22.4$ litres
**This is a universal constant for ideal gases at STP**

given: STP conditions: T = 273 K, P = 1 atm

question_plain: Figure 12.8 shows plot of PV/T versus P for 1.00×10⁻³ kg of oxygen gas at two different temperatures. (a) What does the dotted plot signify? (b) Which is true: T₁ > T₂ or T₁ < T₂? (c) What is the value of PV/T where the curves meet on the y-axis? (d) If we obtained similar plots for 1.00×10⁻³ kg of hydrogen, would we get the same value of PV/T at the point where the curves meet on the y-axis? If not, what mass of hydrogen yields the same value of PV/T (for low pressure high temperature region of the plot)? (Molecular mass of H₂ = 2.02 u, of O₂ = 32.0 u, R = 8.31 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹.)
question_latex: Figure 12.8 shows plot of $PV/T$ versus $P$ for $1.00 \times 10^{-3}$ kg of oxygen gas at two different temperatures. (a) What does the dotted plot signify? (b) Which is true: $T_1 > T_2$ or $T_1 < T_2$? (c) What is the value of $PV/T$ where the curves meet on the y-axis? (d) If we obtained similar plots for $1.00 \times 10^{-3}$ kg of hydrogen, would we get the same value of $PV/T$ at the point where the curves meet on the y-axis? If not, what mass of hydrogen yields the same value of $PV/T$ (for low pressure high temperature region of the plot)? (Molecular mass of H$_2$ = $2.02$ u, of O$_2$ = $32.0$ u, $R = 8.31$ J mol$^{-1}$ K$^{-1}$.)
correct_answer_plain: (a) The dotted plot corresponds to 'ideal' gas behaviour; (b) T₁ > T₂; (c) 0.26 J K⁻¹; (d) No, 6.3×10⁻⁵ kg of H₂ would yield the same value
correct_answer_latex: (a) The dotted plot corresponds to 'ideal' gas behaviour; (b) $T_1 > T_2$; (c) $0.26$ J K$^{-1}$; (d) No, $6.3 \times 10^{-5}$ kg of H$_2$ would yield the same value
hint: At low P, gases behave ideally: PV/T = nR. Real gases deviate at high P. Higher T → less deviation.
solution_steps_latex: Molecular mass of O$_2$: $M_{O_2} = 32.0$ u $= 32.0$ g/mol
Molecular mass of H$_2$: $M_{H_2} = 2.02$ u $= 2.02$ g/mol
For ideal gas: $PV = nRT$ → $\frac{PV}{T} = nR = $ constant (independent of $P$)
Real gases approach ideal behavior at:
• **Low pressure** (molecules far apart, negligible intermolecular forces)
• **High temperature** (high kinetic energy overcomes intermolecular forces)
From graph: Curve for $T_1$ is **closer to ideal behavior** (dotted line) than $T_2$
At higher temperatures, gases behave more ideally
**(c) Value of PV/T at y-axis intercept:**
Number of moles of H$_2$ with mass $1.00 \times 10^{-3}$ kg:
This is **different** from oxygen's value ($0.26$ J K$^{-1}$)

visual_content.diagram_description: Graph of PV/T vs P showing two curves at different temperatures T₁ and T₂, with a horizontal dotted line representing ideal gas behavior

to_find: Mass of H₂ for same PV/T

question_plain: An oxygen cylinder of volume 30 litre has an initial gauge pressure of 15 atm and a temperature of 27 °C. After some oxygen is withdrawn from the cylinder, the gauge pressure drops to 11 atm and its temperature drops to 17 °C. Estimate the mass of oxygen taken out of the cylinder (R = 8.31 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹, molecular mass of O₂ = 32 u).
question_latex: An oxygen cylinder of volume $30$ litre has an initial gauge pressure of $15$ atm and a temperature of $27$ °C. After some oxygen is withdrawn from the cylinder, the gauge pressure drops to $11$ atm and its temperature drops to $17$ °C. Estimate the mass of oxygen taken out of the cylinder ($R = 8.31$ J mol$^{-1}$ K$^{-1}$, molecular mass of O$_2$ = $32$ u).
hint: Use PV=nRT for initial and final states. Gauge pressure = absolute pressure - 1 atm. Find Δn, then mass.
solution_steps_latex: Molecular mass of O$_2$: $M = 32$ g/mol $= 32 \times 10^{-3}$ kg/mol
**Note:** Gauge pressure = Absolute pressure - Atmospheric pressure
**Answer:** Mass of oxygen taken out is $0.14$ kg $= 140$ g

formulas_used: Absolute pressure = Gauge pressure + Atmospheric pressure

question_plain: An air bubble of volume 1.0 cm³ rises from the bottom of a lake 40 m deep at a temperature of 12 °C. To what volume does it grow when it reaches the surface, which is at a temperature of 35 °C?
question_latex: An air bubble of volume $1.0$ cm$^3$ rises from the bottom of a lake $40$ m deep at a temperature of $12$ °C. To what volume does it grow when it reaches the surface, which is at a temperature of $35$ °C?
hint: Use combined gas law: P₁V₁/T₁ = P₂V₂/T₂. At depth, P = P_atm + ρgh. At surface, P = P_atm.
solution_steps_latex: **Answer:** The bubble grows to a volume of $5.3$ cm$^3$
**Volume increases by factor of $\approx 5.3$ due to:**
• Decrease in pressure (dominant effect: 4.93 atm → 1 atm)
• Increase in temperature (minor effect: 285 K → 308 K)

question_plain: Estimate the total number of air molecules (inclusive of oxygen, nitrogen, water vapour and other constituents) in a room of capacity 25.0 m³ at a temperature of 27 °C and 1 atm pressure.
question_latex: Estimate the total number of air molecules (inclusive of oxygen, nitrogen, water vapour and other constituents) in a room of capacity $25.0$ m$^3$ at a temperature of $27$ °C and $1$ atm pressure.
hint: Use PV = nRT to find moles, then N = n × N_A.
solution_steps_latex: **Step 1:** Number of moles using ideal gas equation:
• This enormous number justifies statistical treatment in kinetic theory
• Individual molecular behavior averages out to give macroscopic gas properties

question_plain: Estimate the average thermal energy of a helium atom at (i) room temperature (27 °C), (ii) the temperature on the surface of the Sun (6000 K), (iii) the temperature of 10 million kelvin (the typical core temperature in the case of a star).
question_latex: Estimate the average thermal energy of a helium atom at (i) room temperature ($27$ °C), (ii) the temperature on the surface of the Sun ($6000$ K), (iii) the temperature of $10$ million kelvin (the typical core temperature in the case of a star).
solution_steps_latex: **(ii) On the surface of the Sun:**
• Sun's surface: $20$ times room temperature energy
• Stellar core: $10^5$ times room temperature energy
**Note:** At stellar core temperatures, atoms are completely ionized (plasma state)

to_find: Average thermal energy at three temperatures

section: Molecular Speeds and Degrees of Freedom
question_plain: Three vessels of equal capacity have gases at the same temperature and pressure. The first vessel contains neon (monatomic), the second contains chlorine (diatomic), and the third contains uranium hexafluoride (polyatomic). Do the vessels contain equal number of respective molecules? Is the root mean square speed of molecules the same in the three cases? If not, in which case is v_rms the largest?
question_latex: Three vessels of equal capacity have gases at the same temperature and pressure. The first vessel contains neon (monatomic), the second contains chlorine (diatomic), and the third contains uranium hexafluoride (polyatomic). Do the vessels contain equal number of respective molecules? Is the root mean square speed of molecules the same in the three cases? If not, in which case is $v_{rms}$ the largest?
correct_answer_plain: Yes, according to Avogadro's law. No, v_rms is largest for the lightest of the three gases; neon.
correct_answer_latex: Yes, according to Avogadro's law. No, $v_{rms}$ is largest for the lightest of the three gases; neon.
hint: Same P,V,T → same n (Avogadro's law). v_rms = √(3RT/M) depends on molar mass M.
solution_steps_latex: **Part 1: Do vessels contain equal number of molecules?**
**Avogadro's Law:** Equal volumes of gases at same $P$ and $T$ contain equal number of molecules
If $P$, $V$, and $T$ are same → $n$ (number of moles) is same
Since $n$ is same and $N_A$ is constant:
**All three vessels contain equal number of molecules**
**$v_{rms}$ is inversely proportional to square root of molar mass**
Neon molecules move almost twice as fast as chlorine and over 4 times faster than UF$_6$

given: Equal V, P, T for three gases

question_plain: At what temperature is the root mean square speed of an atom in an argon gas cylinder equal to the rms speed of a helium gas atom at –20 °C? (atomic mass of Ar = 39.9 u, of He = 4.0 u).
question_latex: At what temperature is the root mean square speed of an atom in an argon gas cylinder equal to the rms speed of a helium gas atom at $-20$ °C? (atomic mass of Ar = $39.9$ u, of He = $4.0$ u).
hint: v_rms = √(3RT/M). Set v_Ar = v_He and solve for T_Ar.
solution_steps_latex: **Answer:** Temperature of argon must be $2520$ K (or about $2247$ °C)
• Argon atoms are about $10$ times heavier than helium
• To achieve same speed, argon needs about $10$ times higher temperature
• This shows the inverse relationship between molar mass and temperature for same speed

to_find: Temperature of Ar for same v_rms as He

section: Mean Free Path and Collision Frequency
question_plain: Estimate the mean free path and collision frequency of a nitrogen molecule in a cylinder containing nitrogen at 2.0 atm and temperature 17 °C. Take the radius of a nitrogen molecule to be roughly 1.0 Å. Compare the collision time with the time the molecule moves freely between two successive collisions (Molecular mass of N₂ = 28.0 u).
question_latex: Estimate the mean free path and collision frequency of a nitrogen molecule in a cylinder containing nitrogen at $2.0$ atm and temperature $17$ °C. Take the radius of a nitrogen molecule to be roughly $1.0$ Å. Compare the collision time with the time the molecule moves freely between two successive collisions (Molecular mass of N$_2$ = $28.0$ u).
correct_answer_plain: Mean free path: 1.0×10⁻⁷ m; Collision frequency: 5.1×10⁹ s⁻¹; Collision time: 4×10⁻¹³ s; Free time: 2×10⁻¹⁰ s; Free time is 500 times collision time.
correct_answer_latex: Mean free path: $1.0 \times 10^{-7}$ m; Collision frequency: $5.1 \times 10^9$ s$^{-1}$; Collision time: $4 \times 10^{-13}$ s; Free time: $2 \times 10^{-10}$ s; Free time is $500$ times collision time.
hint: λ = 1/(√2 π d² n). Find n from PV=NkT. v_rms for collision frequency. Time = distance/speed.
solution_steps_latex: Radius of N$_2$ molecule: $r = 1.0$ Å $= 1.0 \times 10^{-10}$ m
Distance covered during collision $\approx d = 2.0 \times 10^{-10}$ m
• Molecule spends $500$ times longer moving freely than colliding
• About $99.8\%$ of time is spent in free flight
• Molecules move essentially free for most of the time

to_find: Comparison of collision time and free time
